chapter.summary: Covers the management and referral of non-septic and septic pre-patellar bursitis.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I admit or refer a person with pre-patellar bursitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange urgent admission if the person:
    • Is systemically unwell (for example fever over 38°C, tachycardia, hypotension or increased respiratory rate).
    • Has severe septic bursitis or severe infection of the surrounding tissue.
    • Is immunocompromised or has other serious comorbidities, such as diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Has developed an abscess requiring incision and drainage.
  • Refer urgently to orthopaedics or seek specialist advice if:
    • The person has septic bursitis which is not responding, or is responding inadequately, to antibiotic treatment — a change in antibiotic, intravenous antibiotic, or surgery may be required.
  • Refer the person to orthopaedics (with urgency depending on clinical judgement) if they have:
    • Recurrent septic bursitis — surgical excision of the bursa may be required.
    • A chronically discharging sinus — surgical excision may be required.
    • Non-septic chronic bursitis, which:
      • Is not responding to conservative measures, or,
      • Is associated with significant recurrent swelling and/or pain.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to admit or refer a person with pre-patellar bursitis are based on expert opinion in review articles [Aaron et al, 2011; Hanrahan, 2013; Baumbach et al, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].

Admission
  • People with systemic signs of infection or inflammation or who are immunocompromised should be admitted to hospital for intravenous antibiotic treatment [Baumbach et al, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
  • People who are seriously ill or who have severe septic-bursitis with necrosis of the overlying skin or severe infection of the surrounding soft tissue require immediate surgical intervention [Baumbach et al, 2014].
Referral
  • Orthopaedic opinion is advised if bursitis is recurrent  [BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
  • Surgical treatment may be required in people with persistent infection despite appropriate antibiotic treatment, infection with an organism that is difficult to treat (such as environmental fungi), sepsis, underlying osteomyelitis, abscess, fistula, skin necrosis, foreign body, or in cases of non-septic bursitis which are refractory to treatment, chronic or recurrent [Aaron et al, 2011; Hanrahan, 2013; Baumbach et al, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage pre-patellar bursitis in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If the person is well and does not need admission or referral, uncomplicated bursitis can be managed in primary care.

  • If clinically confident that the person has non-septic bursitis:
    • Advise the person to rest the knee and to modify or avoid activities which worsen symptoms (such as prolonged kneeling or pressure over the knee).
      • Activity modification may be difficult if bursitis has been precipitated by occupation — protective padding may help in avoiding further trauma.
    • Advise the person to try simple measures to ease symptoms such as:
      • Ice — apply though a thin towel to the affected area intermittently for 10 minutes at a time, every few hours. Ice should not be applied directly to the skin.
      • Compression.
      • Elevation.
      • Simple analgesia — paracetamol or non-steroidal anti-inflammatories [NSAIDs] can be used to ease discomfort.
    • Advise the person to seek medical advice immediately if any symptoms of infection or complications develop.
    • Arrange review if symptoms are not settling — if conservative measures fail discuss further management with, or refer to orthopaedics (with urgency dependant on clinical judgement).
      • Intra-bursal corticosteroid injection may be considered by specialists on an individual basis if conservative treatment fails, infection has been ruled out and the person has high occupational demands or is an athlete.
      • Bursal aspiration and corticosteroid injection are not recommended routinely for the treatment of aseptic bursitis due to a lack of supporting evidence and risk of adverse effects such as infection, skin atrophy, and chronic pain.
  • If uncomplicated septic bursitis is suspected, the person is well, does not require admission or referral and appropriate follow up can be arranged:
    • Aspirate bursal fluid using an aseptic technique (if expertise and equipment are available) prior to starting antibiotics to allow confirmation of infection and microbial sensitivities.
      • If the expertise and equipment for aspiration are not available in primary care discuss urgently with orthopaedics.
    • Treat empirically with an oral antibiotic which covers staphylococci and streptococci species (unless there is reason to suspect another organism) while awaiting confirmation of infection and sensitivities from the laboratory.
      • For further information on the antibiotic treatment of septic bursitis, see the sections on Management and Prescribing in the CKS topic on Olecranon bursitis.
    • If in doubt about choice of antibiotic or diagnosis seek expert advice.
      • Inadequate initial antibiotic therapy may lead to complications and admission.
    • Advise the person on conservative measures (rest, activity modification, protective padding, ice, elevation and simple analgesia) as for non-septic bursitis.
    • Arrange follow up 2 days after initial assessment (sooner if symptoms are worsening) and every few days thereafter until symptoms have completely resolved.
      • Assess effectiveness of treatment and adjust antibiotics in line with culture results if needed.
      • Oral antibiotics can be continued for 2 weeks depending on response.
      • If infection fails to resolve, worsens or complications develop – seek urgent specialist advice regarding admission and further management.
    • Optimise management of associated conditions — for further information see the CKS topics on Gout, Rheumatoid arthritis, and Cellulitis - acute.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Specialist assessment and management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Specialist assessment and management may involve:

  • Aspiration to differentiate between septic and non-septic bursitis (X-ray in 2 planes and ultrasound may be carried out before aspiration).
  • If septic bursitis is confirmed:
    • Antibiotic treatment (in some cases intravenous).
    • Surgery (incision and drainage, partial or complete bursectomy) may be required if bursitis persists despite appropriate antibiotic therapy, an abscess or sinus has formed or there is underlying osteomyelitis or a foreign body.
  • If non-septic bursitis is confirmed:
    • Intra-bursal corticosteroid injection may be considered when conservative treatment fails, infection has been ruled out and the person has high occupational demands or is an athlete.
    • Bursectomy may be considered for persistent or recurrent non-septic bursitis.

[Aaron et al, 2011; Chalmers, 2012; Hanrahan, 2013; Baumbach et al, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of bursitis are based on a clinical guideline from the American College of Occupational and Environmental Medicine (ACOEM) Knee disorders [ACOEM, 2011] and expert opinion in review articles [Aaron et al, 2011; Chalmers, 2012; Hanrahan, 2013; Hong, 2014; Baumbach et al, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].

  • Although the strategies described in the management of pre-patellar bursitis are common in practice there is little robust clinical evidence to support them [ACOEM, 2011; Baumbach et al, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
Rest and modification of activities

The ACOEM recommends modifying activities and allowing time to reabsorb fluid in knee bursitis — this recommendation is based on consensus as supporting evidence was found to be insufficient or irreconcilable [ACOEM, 2011].

Soft padding of the knee and compression
  • The ACOEM recommends soft padding of the knee and elastic compression bandaging in knee bursitis — this recommendation is based on consensus as supporting evidence was found to be insufficient or irreconcilable [ACOEM, 2011].
Simple analgesia
  • Expert opinion in review articles supports the use of simple analgesia (in particular non-steroidal anti-inflammatories [NSAIDs]) in the management of pre-patellar bursitis [Aaron et al, 2011; Baumbach et al, 2014; Hong, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
  • ACOEM do not recommend for or against routine use of NSAIDs in the routine management of knee bursitis due to insufficient evidence [ACOEM, 2011].
Aspiration
  • A rapid response report from the Canadian Agency for Drugs and Technologies and Drugs in Health (CADTH) found no relevant literature related to the effectiveness of aspiration as a treatment for pre-patellar and olecranon bursitis in adults [CADTH, 2012].
Intra-bursal injection in non-septic bursitis
  • Corticosteroid injection is not recommended routinely for the treatment of aseptic bursitis due to a lack of supporting evidence and risk of adverse effects such as infection, skin atrophy, and chronic pain [Aaron et al, 2011; Chalmers, 2012; Baumbach et al, 2014].
  • ACOEM do not recommend for or against the routine use of glucocorticosteroid injection in the routine management of knee bursitis due to insufficient evidence. However, based on consensus opinion, the guideline suggests that they may be a reasonable option in people with symptoms which do not respond to conservative measures before surgery is considered [ACOEM, 2011].
  • Corticosteroid injection should be avoided in septic bursitis [Hong, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
Antibiotics in septic bursitis
  • Antibiotic therapy is recommended for successful treatment of septic bursitis. Mild to moderate cases (where the person is systemically well) can be treated with oral antibiotics on an outpatient basis [Baumbach et al, 2014].
  • Empirical antibiotics should be started while awaiting confirmation of infection and sensitivities from the laboratory. Choice of empirical antibiotic is based on the likely infecting pathogen (80–90 percent of septic bursitis is due to infection with Staphylococcus aureus) [Hanrahan, 2013; Baumbach et al, 2014].
    • Antibiotic therapy should be switched, if necessary, once sensitivities are available [Baumbach et al, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
  • There is no consensus in the literature in relation to the duration of antibiotic administration and expert opinion varies.
    • One review article states that in mild to moderate cases of septic bursitis, oral antibiotics can be given for 2 weeks [Baumbach et al, 2014]. In some cases, depending on individual response, treatment may be required for a longer period [BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
    • CKS recommends seeking specialist advice if longer periods of treatment are required. This recommendation is based on a document from the Commission on Human Medicines (formerly the Committee on Safety of Medicines) which states that cholestatic jaundice and hepatitis may occur with administration of flucloxacillin, particularly if the person is treated for more than 2 weeks and is elderly [CSM, 2004].
Follow up
  • Expert opinion in review articles recommend close follow-up and monitoring of treatment in septic bursitis [Baumbach et al, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
  • The recommendation to seek specialist advice if treatment in primary care fails, symptoms worsen or complications develop is based on what CKS considers to be best practice.
